title: Botulism
icd10: A48.59 (Other specified botulism — adult intestinal colonization
scope: ** Diagnosis and management of all forms of botulism: foodborne (toxin ingestion), wound (toxin produced in infected wound), iatrogenic (therapeutic botulinum toxin overdose), infant botulism (intestinal colonization in infants), and adult intestinal colonization. Covers acute recognition of descending flaccid paralysis, respiratory monitoring (NIF/FVC), antitoxin administration (heptavalent equine antitoxin via CDC), electrophysiologic diagnosis, differentiation from GBS/MG/stroke, and supportive ICU care. Excludes cosmetic botulinum toxin use without adverse effect and bioterrorism-specific protocols (notify public health).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; infection screen; wound botulism may show leukocytosis
Electrolyte abnormalities; renal/hepatic function; baseline for prolonged ICU course
Hypomagnesemia worsens neuromuscular weakness; can compound paralysis
Hypophosphatemia can worsen respiratory muscle weakness
Critical illness hyperglycemia management; autonomic dysfunction
Respiratory failure assessment; early CO2 retention precedes hypoxia
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal pH, pCO2 <45 mmHg; rising pCO2 indicates impending respiratory failure

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Coagulation status before procedures; wound botulism may need surgical debridement
Wound botulism — rule out secondary bacteremia; exclude sepsis
Baseline; UTI as complication in prolonged hospitalization
Antitoxin is equine-derived — pregnancy category C; imaging considerations
Assess tissue perfusion; distinguish from septic shock
Potential need for surgical intervention (wound botulism); ICU procedures

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Definitive diagnostic test; contact CDC/state health department for testing; sensitivity 33-44% in serum
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Positive confirms diagnosis (negative does NOT exclude)

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: Stool botulinum toxin assay and culture (CPT 87045)
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Higher sensitivity than serum (60%+ in foodborne); also identifies colonization (infant, adult intestinal)
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Positive toxin or culture of C. botulinum

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Wound botulism — culture for C. botulinum; send tissue/exudate for anaerobic culture and toxin assay
Epidemiologic confirmation; send to state public health lab via CDC coordination
Identifies toxin serotype to guide antitoxin selection; types A, B, E most common in humans
Inflammatory markers; elevated in wound botulism
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal in foodborne; elevated in wound botulism

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Elevated in some neuromuscular conditions; usually normal in botulism; rhabdomyolysis from prolonged immobility

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Exclude GBS variants if diagnostic uncertainty persists
Differentiates from MG (positive in MG, negative in botulism); rarely performed now
Ascending paralysis mimic; search skin/scalp for embedded tick
Cholinergic crisis differential (excess secretions + weakness); toxicology screen
CSF normal in botulism; elevated protein with normal cells suggests GBS; pleocytosis suggests infection
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal in botulism (protein normal, WBC normal)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Acute intermittent porphyria — motor neuropathy + autonomic dysfunction mimic

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Normal WBC distinguishes from GBS (albuminocytologic dissociation) and meningitis
Normal in botulism; elevated in GBS
Lumbar Puncture.target: NORMAL (<45 mg/dL) — elevated protein favors GBS

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Normal in botulism; low in bacterial meningitis

Essential/First-line.item: Nerve conduction studies (NCS) (CPT 95907-95913) / EMG (CPT 95886) with repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) (CPT 95937)
Essential/First-line.timing: As soon as available (ideally within 24-48h); diagnostic cornerstone
Essential/First-line.target: Reduced CMAP amplitudes; normal sensory nerve action potentials (SNAPs); INCREMENTAL response (facilitation) at high-rate (20-50 Hz) repetitive stimulation (post-exercise facilitation); normal or mildly prolonged distal latencies; brief-duration, small-amplitude motor unit potentials (BSAPs) on needle EMG; fibrillation potentials in severe cases
Aspiration pneumonia; atelectasis; baseline for ventilator management; mediastinal mass (differential)
Sinus tachycardia; conduction abnormalities; autonomic effects on cardiac rhythm

Essential/First-line.timing: On admission if stroke in differential

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Extended.target: Normal in botulism; excludes brainstem stroke, demyelination, mass

Extended.item: MRI spine with and without contrast (CPT 72156)
Extended.target: Normal in botulism; excludes spinal cord compression

Extended.timing: If thymoma suspected (MG differential) or pulmonary complication
Extended.target: No thymoma; assess for aspiration pneumonia

Extended.timing: If deep abscess suspected as source of wound botulism
At 1-2 weeks if initial study non-diagnostic or to assess recovery
Extended.target: Evolution of findings; improving CMAPs indicate recovery

Extended.timing: If hemodynamic instability or autonomic dysfunction

Rare/Specialized.target: Increased jitter and blocking (present in botulism but non-specific — also seen in MG, LEMS)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If borderline respiratory function during recovery

Acute/Emergent.item: Heptavalent botulinum antitoxin (HBAT) (equine-derived, serotypes A-G) — obtained from CDC (CPT 96365, 96366)
Acute/Emergent.indication: All forms of botulism (foodborne, wound, adult intestinal colonization, inhalational); administer as early as possible — antitoxin neutralizes circulating toxin but does NOT reverse already-bound toxin

doseOptions.orderSentence: Heptavalent botulinum antitoxin (HBAT) (equine-derived, serotypes A-G) — obtained from CDC (CPT 96365, 96366) 1 vial IV

dosing.instructions: 1 vial (containing equine-derived antibodies to types A-G) IV; dilute 1:10 in 0.9% NS; infuse slowly over 15-30 min initially, increase rate per CDC protocol; contact CDC Emergency Operations Center 770-488-7100 (24/7) to obtain antitoxin; administer as soon as clinical suspicion is high — do NOT wait for lab confirmation
dosing.orderSentence: Heptavalent botulinum antitoxin (HBAT) (equine-derived, serotypes A-G) — obtained from CDC (CPT 96365, 96366) 1 vial IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: History of equine protein hypersensitivity (perform skin test first per CDC protocol); serum sickness risk 5-10% (monitor for 10-21 days post-infusion)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Skin test before infusion if history of atopy or equine exposure; monitor VS q5min during infusion and q15min x 4h post; observe for anaphylaxis (epinephrine at bedside); delayed serum sickness (fever, rash, arthralgias at 10-21 days)

Acute/Emergent.indication: Infant botulism ONLY (age <1 year); FDA-approved for infant botulism types A and B

doseOptions.orderSentence: BabyBIG (botulism immune globulin intravenous, human) (CPT 96365, 96366) 50 mg/kg IV

dosing.instructions: 50 mg/kg (1 mL/kg) IV single dose; infuse at 0.5 mL/kg/h initially, increase to 1.0 mL/kg/h if tolerated; obtain from California Infant Botulism Treatment and Prevention Program (IBTPP) at 510-231-7600 (24/7)
dosing.orderSentence: BabyBIG (botulism immune globulin intravenous, human) (CPT 96365, 96366) 50 mg/kg IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: IgA deficiency; prior severe reaction to human immunoglobulin
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Vital signs q15min during infusion; watch for anaphylaxis; renal function

Acute/Emergent.indication: Respiratory failure — single most important cause of death in botulism

dosing.instructions: Indications: FVC <15-20 mL/kg, NIF weaker than -30 cmH2O, >30% decline in FVC from baseline, rising pCO2, clinical respiratory distress, inability to protect airway due to bulbar weakness. Use non-depolarizing agents (rocuronium preferred). AVOID succinylcholine (risk of exaggerated response in denervated muscle). Anticipate PROLONGED ventilation (weeks to months)

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Ventilator settings per ICU protocol; daily assessment; plan for tracheostomy if ventilation expected >14 days

Acute/Emergent.indication: Wound botulism — remove source of ongoing toxin production; perform AFTER antitoxin administration to avoid releasing more toxin into circulation

doseOptions.orderSentence: Wound debridement and drainage (wound botulism) N/A Surgical

dosing.instructions: Thorough surgical debridement of infected wound; drain abscess if present; obtain tissue for anaerobic culture; perform AFTER antitoxin has been given
dosing.orderSentence: Wound debridement and drainage (wound botulism) N/A Surgical

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Wound site; CBC; signs of secondary infection

Acute/Emergent.indication: Wound botulism — eradicate C. botulinum from wound; adjunct to debridement

dosing.instructions: 500 mg IV q8h x 10-14 days; alternative to penicillin (avoids aminoglycoside interaction concern)

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; disulfiram-like reaction with alcohol

Acute/Emergent.indication: Wound botulism — alternative to metronidazole for C. botulinum eradication

doseOptions.orderSentence: Penicillin G (wound botulism — alternative) (CPT 96365) 3 million units IV

dosing.instructions: 3 million units IV q4h x 10-14 days
dosing.orderSentence: Penicillin G (wound botulism — alternative) (CPT 96365) 3 million units IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Penicillin allergy; AVOID aminoglycosides concurrently (potentiate neuromuscular blockade)

Acute/Emergent.indication: Immobilized patients at high risk of VTE

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dvt Prophylaxis: Enoxaparin 30 mg SC BID
Dvt Prophylaxis: Enoxaparin 40 mg SC daily

dosing.instructions: 40 mg SC daily; start on admission
dosing.orderSentence: Dvt Prophylaxis: Enoxaparin 30 mg SC BID

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Platelets q3 days; anti-Xa if renal impairment

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dvt Prophylaxis: Heparin Sc 5000 units SC q8h
Dvt Prophylaxis: Heparin Sc 5000 units SC q12h

dosing.instructions: 5000 units SC q8-12h
dosing.orderSentence: Dvt Prophylaxis: Heparin Sc 5000 units SC q8h

dosing.instructions: Apply bilaterally on admission; continue until ambulatory

Acute/Emergent.indication: Dehydration from GI prodrome (foodborne botulism — nausea, vomiting, diarrhea)

doseOptions.orderSentence: IV fluid resuscitation (0.9% NS) (CPT 96360, 96361) 20 mL/kg IV

dosing.instructions: 20 mL/kg IV bolus, then maintenance; target euvolemia
dosing.orderSentence: IV fluid resuscitation (0.9% NS) (CPT 96360, 96361) 20 mL/kg IV

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Bradycardia from autonomic dysfunction; excessive secretions

dosing.instructions: 0.5-1 mg IV PRN for symptomatic bradycardia; may repeat q3-5 min; max 3 mg

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Excessive oral secretions (antisialagogue); preferred over atropine for secretion management

dosing.instructions: 0.2 mg IV q4-6h PRN; or 1-2 mg PO TID
650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 4g/day (2g if hepatic impairment)
10 mg IV q6h PRN; max 40 mg/day; limit to <12 weeks

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Seizure history, Parkinson disease, GI obstruction

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nausea and vomiting (foodborne botulism GI symptoms)

dosing.instructions: 4 mg IV q6-8h PRN
100 mg PO BID
8.6-17.2 mg PO qHS
17 g PO daily in 8 oz water

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Dry eyes from impaired blinking (CN VII involvement, reduced lacrimation)

dosing.instructions: 1-2 drops each eye q2-4h while awake; lubricating ointment at night

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Corneal integrity; ophthalmology if corneal exposure

dosing.instructions: 3-5 mg PO qHS
0.5-1 mg IV q6-8h PRN; use with caution — may worsen hypotonia

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Respiratory depression (extreme caution if not intubated)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: RR, sedation scale; avoid in non-intubated patients

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Historical agent to enhance acetylcholine release at NMJ; limited efficacy; NOT standard of care; may provide modest improvement in chronic phase

dosing.instructions: 15-35 mg/kg/day divided TID-QID; start low and titrate; limited evidence for benefit

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: CBC, BMP weekly; bone marrow toxicity (aplastic anemia reported)

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Potassium channel blocker to enhance neuromuscular transmission; off-label, limited evidence; may improve strength in recovery phase

dosing.instructions: 10 mg PO BID (extended-release); off-label use

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Prolonged mechanical ventilation (>14 days expected — common in botulism)

dosing.instructions: Perform when ventilation anticipated >14 days; improves patient comfort, oral hygiene, weaning potential

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Stoma site; decannulation readiness in recovery

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Prolonged inability to swallow safely; enteral nutrition access

dosing.instructions: Place when dysphagia expected to persist >2-3 weeks

Recovery/Rehabilitation Therapies.indication: All botulism patients; early passive ROM to prevent contractures; progressive strengthening during recovery

dosing.instructions: Daily passive ROM while paralyzed; active-assisted exercises as strength returns; progressive strengthening and gait training in recovery

Recovery/Rehabilitation Therapies.indication: Upper extremity function, ADLs, adaptive equipment

dosing.instructions: Daily OT for fine motor recovery, ADL training, adaptive equipment

Recovery/Rehabilitation Therapies.indication: Dysphagia evaluation and treatment; aspiration prevention; communication strategies if intubated/trached

dosing.instructions: Bedside swallow evaluation; instrumental assessment (FEES or MBS) before oral intake; speech/communication strategies

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation — all suspected botulism; diagnostic confirmation; EMG/NCS interpretation; differentiation from GBS, MG, stroke
Critical care / Pulmonology — respiratory monitoring and ventilator management; all patients with bulbar or respiratory weakness
Infectious disease — confirm diagnosis; guide antibiotic therapy for wound botulism; coordinate public health notification

Public health / CDC notification — MANDATORY: botulism is a nationally notifiable disease; contact state health department AND CDC Emergency Operations Center (770-488-7100) to obtain antitoxin and for epidemiologic investigation
Toxicology / Poison control — if foodborne: identify implicated food; coordinate with public health; differential diagnosis assistance
Surgery (wound botulism) — wound debridement and drainage for wound botulism; abscess management in IVDU patients
Speech-language pathology (SLP) — dysphagia evaluation; aspiration prevention; communication strategies
Physical therapy (PT) — early passive ROM; progressive mobilization; gait training in recovery
Occupational therapy (OT) — upper extremity function; ADLs; adaptive equipment
Rehabilitation medicine (physiatry) — rehabilitation planning; disposition (inpatient rehab vs SNF vs home)
Respiratory therapy — bedside spirometry (FVC, NIF); pulmonary toilet; ventilator weaning protocols
Ophthalmology — if persistent diplopia, ptosis, or corneal exposure from impaired blinking
Nutrition / Dietitian — enteral/parenteral feeding plan if prolonged dysphagia; caloric needs during recovery
Social work — discharge planning; family support; financial resources for prolonged hospitalization
Psychology / Psychiatry — anxiety, depression, PTSD (common with prolonged ICU stay and ventilator dependence)

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED / Call 911 if: increasing difficulty breathing, new swallowing difficulty, worsening double vision, progressive weakness, inability to hold up head, chest pain, or lightheadedness
Botulism is a serious but treatable condition; early antitoxin administration improves outcomes
Recovery is typically slow (weeks to months); full recovery is possible but may take up to a year
Do NOT drive until vision (diplopia), strength, and reflexes have fully recovered and cleared by neurologist
Comply with physical and occupational therapy exercises as prescribed
Report any new difficulty breathing, swallowing, or worsening weakness immediately

Foodborne botulism prevention: do not eat food from bulging or damaged cans; properly refrigerate foods; follow safe home canning practices (pressure canning for low-acid foods; boil home-canned foods for 10 min before eating)
Wound botulism (IVDU patients): avoid injection drug use; if continuing, use clean needles and do not skin-pop or muscle-pop; seek help for substance use disorder
Follow-up with neurology in 1-2 weeks after discharge; NCS/EMG may be repeated at 3-6 months to document recovery
Inform future healthcare providers about botulism history (anesthesia precautions — prolonged paralysis risk with certain agents)
Fall prevention: use assistive devices as recommended during recovery; remove tripping hazards at home
Monitor for signs of blood clots: leg swelling, redness, chest pain, shortness of breath

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Gradual return to activity as tolerated; avoid overexertion during recovery; fatigue is common for months
Safe food handling: proper canning techniques (pressure canning at 250F/121C for low-acid foods); refrigerate perishables; discard bulging, leaking, or damaged cans
Boil home-canned foods for 10 minutes before eating (destroys botulinum toxin)
Honey should NOT be given to infants <1 year (infant botulism risk from Clostridium spores)
Wound care: keep wounds clean; seek medical attention for infected wounds especially in IVDU patients
Substance use disorder treatment referral for IVDU patients with wound botulism
Balanced nutrition for neuromuscular recovery (adequate protein, B vitamins)
Mental health support (prolonged ICU stay, ventilator dependence, slow recovery cause significant psychological stress)
Smoking cessation (impairs tissue healing and neuromuscular recovery)

differential.features: ASCENDING paralysis (starts distally, moves proximally — opposite of botulism); sensory symptoms common; areflexia; CSF shows elevated protein with normal WBC (albuminocytologic dissociation); no pupil involvement; no GI prodrome typical of botulism
differential.tests: NCS/EMG (demyelinating or axonal pattern; NO incremental response); LP (elevated protein); anti-ganglioside antibodies

differential.features: Fatigable weakness; fluctuating symptoms; ptosis and diplopia (similar to botulism); intact pupillary reflexes; no GI prodrome; chronic course
differential.tests: AChR/MuSK antibodies; repetitive nerve stimulation shows DECREMENTAL response at LOW-rate (2-3 Hz) stimulation (vs. incremental at high-rate in botulism); edrophonium test positive

differential.features: Proximal weakness; hyporeflexia with post-exercise facilitation; autonomic dysfunction (dry mouth); associated with SCLC; chronic onset
differential.tests: NCS shows incremental response at high-rate RNS (SIMILAR to botulism); VGCC antibodies positive; CT chest for malignancy

differential.features: Acute onset; focal neurologic deficits; cranial nerve findings may overlap; crossed findings (ipsilateral face, contralateral body); no GI prodrome; no descending pattern
differential.tests: MRI brain with DWI (acute infarct); CTA/MRA (vascular occlusion); normal NCS/EMG

differential.features: Ascending paralysis similar to GBS; rapid onset; tick found on exam; rapid reversal after tick removal; no sensory loss; normal CSF
differential.tests: Physical exam (search for tick — scalp, hairline, skin folds); NCS may show reduced CMAPs; CSF normal

differential.features: Cholinergic crisis: SLUDGE symptoms (salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, GI distress, emesis); miosis; muscle fasciculations then weakness; bradycardia
differential.tests: Cholinesterase levels (depressed); atropine challenge (improves symptoms); toxicology screen

differential.features: Pharyngeal membrane; palatal weakness early; sensorimotor neuropathy develops weeks after infection; myocarditis
differential.tests: Throat culture; diphtheria toxin assay; clinical history; travel/vaccination history

differential.features: Abdominal pain (prominent); psychiatric symptoms; autonomic dysfunction; motor-predominant neuropathy; dark urine
differential.tests: Urine ALA and PBG (elevated during attack); genetic testing

differential.features: Asymmetric flaccid paralysis; fever; anterior horn cell pattern; CSF pleocytosis
differential.tests: CSF (elevated WBC); viral PCR; MRI (anterior horn signal change)

differential.features: Similar bulbar and respiratory failure; known MG history typically; rapid deterioration
differential.tests: AChR antibodies; history of MG; decremental response on RNS

differential.features: Acute exacerbation of LEMS; proximal weakness; autonomic symptoms
differential.tests: VGCC antibodies; malignancy screening; high-rate RNS

differential.features: Iatrogenic (MgSO4 infusion); weakness; hyporeflexia; respiratory depression
Non-physiologic weakness pattern; Hoover sign; give-way weakness; may mimic any neurologic presentation
differential.tests: Normal NCS/EMG; normal labs; clinical exam features inconsistent with organic disease

evidence.recommendation: Heptavalent botulinum antitoxin (HBAT) — early administration reduces mortality and duration of illness
evidence.source: [Arnon et al. JAMA 2006](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16893656/); [Tacket et al. Am J Med 1984](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/6720725/)

evidence.recommendation: BabyBIG (human botulism immune globulin) for infant botulism — reduces hospitalization by 3+ weeks
evidence.source: [Arnon et al. N Engl J Med 2006](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16452558/)

evidence.recommendation: EMG/NCS with repetitive nerve stimulation — incremental response at high-rate stimulation diagnostic
evidence.source: [Cherington M. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1982](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/6763148/); [Gutierrez et al. Muscle Nerve 2000](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10639608/)

evidence.recommendation: Mouse bioassay — gold standard for botulinum toxin detection; serum sensitivity ~33-44%
Respiratory monitoring (FVC/NIF) for intubation decisions in neuromuscular respiratory failure
evidence.source: [Lawn et al. Arch Neurol 2001](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11405803/); [Wijdicks & Borel, Neurology 1998](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9443451/)

evidence.recommendation: Wound debridement AFTER antitoxin administration for wound botulism
evidence.source: [Werner et al. Clin Infect Dis 2000](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11049786/); CDC guidelines

evidence.recommendation: Avoid aminoglycosides — potentiate neuromuscular blockade in botulism
Contact CDC Emergency Operations Center (770-488-7100) for antitoxin access
Botulism is a nationally notifiable disease — mandatory reporting
evidence.source: CDC nationally notifiable conditions; state public health law

evidence.recommendation: Do not administer antibiotics in infant botulism (risk of toxin release from bacterial lysis)
evidence.source: [Arnon et al. N Engl J Med 2006](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16452558/); IBTPP guidelines

evidence.recommendation: Prolonged mechanical ventilation expected (median 58 days type A; 26 days type B)

evidence.source: Standard of care for immobilized patients
Standard of care in neuromuscular disease

evidence.recommendation: Metronidazole preferred over aminoglycosides for wound botulism antibiotic therapy
evidence.source: Expert consensus; [Werner et al. Clin Infect Dis 2000](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11049786/)

evidence.recommendation: Succinylcholine avoidance in neuromuscular junction disorders
evidence.source: Risk of hyperkalemia and prolonged blockade

evidence.recommendation: Antitoxin most effective when given within 24h of symptom onset; still beneficial up to 72h
evidence.source: [Tacket et al. Am J Med 1984](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/6720725/); retrospective data

monitoring.frequency: q2-4h in ED/ICU; q4-6h on floor; q1h if declining
monitoring.action: FVC <15-20 mL/kg or declining >30% from baseline -> elective intubation; transfer to ICU
NIF weaker than -30 cmH2O -> prepare for intubation
Airway clearance interventions; suction; assisted cough

monitoring.frequency: Continuous in ICU; q2-4h on floor
monitoring.action: LATE finding — do NOT rely on SpO2 alone; FVC and NIF are far more sensitive indicators of impending failure

monitoring.frequency: q4-6h; more frequently if declining FVC
monitoring.action: Rising pCO2 indicates hypoventilation and impending respiratory failure — intubate

monitoring.frequency: q4h on floor; continuous in ICU
monitoring.action: Hypotension: IV fluids, vasopressors if refractory; AVOID long-acting agents

monitoring.frequency: Continuous in ICU; telemetry on floor
monitoring.action: Bradycardia: atropine; tachycardia: volume, pain control; arrhythmia: per ACLS

monitoring.frequency: q4-8h; focus on pupillary response, ptosis, bulbar function, proximal then distal strength
monitoring.action: Worsening (new cranial nerve palsies, progressing to limbs) -> reassess respiratory status STAT; ensure antitoxin given
Fixed, dilated pupils (mydriasis) suggest botulism (distinguishes from GBS/MG); document progression

monitoring.frequency: Daily assessment; formal SLP if bulbar symptoms
monitoring.action: NPO if unsafe; NG tube or PEG for nutrition
Absent gag -> NPO; aspiration precautions; suction at bedside
Ileus is common (autonomic dysfunction); bowel program; avoid opioids if possible

monitoring.frequency: I/O monitoring; post-void residual if needed
monitoring.action: Urinary retention (autonomic dysfunction) -> bladder scan; intermittent catheterization

monitoring.frequency: Daily in acute phase; q48h when stable

monitoring.action: Signs of infection -> repeat debridement; adjust antibiotics

disposition.criteria: Extremely rare in acute botulism; only for VERY mild cases (minimal weakness, stable respiratory function, no bulbar symptoms); reliable outpatient follow-up; family/caregiver support; neurology follow-up within 1-2 weeks

All suspected botulism should be admitted to ICU or monitored setting; respiratory monitoring (FVC/NIF) required; any bulbar weakness; any respiratory compromise; antitoxin administration and monitoring; autonomic instability
Mild cases after antitoxin with stable respiratory function (FVC >25 mL/kg and stable); no bulbar weakness; able to protect airway; continuous telemetry available; step-down from ICU when improving

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: Need for ICU with neurology and critical care expertise; need for antitoxin (coordinate with CDC for transfer if antitoxin unavailable locally); ECMO capability if refractory respiratory failure
Significant residual motor deficits; able to participate in 3h/day therapy; medically stable; ventilator weaned or stable tracheostomy
Unable to tolerate intensive rehabilitation; requires ongoing nursing care; ventilator-dependent (long-term acute care facility — LTAC)
Prolonged ventilator dependence (common in botulism — weeks to months); requires weaning protocol; medically stable but not ready for rehab
